before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"94fks","text":"You may need to activate a conda environment and/or install python as well as RStudio in order to run these commands. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"60lhh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"ect7r","text":"Data analysis of short-read sequencing from ONT flow cells can be done in a multitude of ways depending on the type of analysis that needs to be done and the sequencer utilized for assembly. Packages like NanoPack are available for use via Python however, there are fewer short-read sequencing packages available in RStudio. This protocol demonstrates how to analyze short-read transcriptome data in Rstudio and Python without the use of cloud-based software like EPI2ME. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mcn6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7d14i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2t1di","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"81s73","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"e7hc5","text":"This protocol was developed for the purposes of BIT 495: Special Topics in Biotechnology: Portable Genome Sequencing at North Carolina State University. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dbk48","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"es26g","text":"Obtain FASTQ files from flow cell (GridION, MinION, PromethION) ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3sg0k","text":"Utilize the Prowler options to build a script to trim your reads based on the adapter lengths produced by the Fasta file. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fnirf","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f3dsn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2i6j0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"61fa0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fjtq","text":"ONT pipeline utilizes guppy software to trim the reads, this protocol recommends the use of Prowler, a novel trimming tool recently developed for Python.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Prowler Trimming command","description":"","guid":"FE01F0ED80FD11EF980A0A58A9FEAC02","name":"\npython3 TrimmerLarge.py -f [filename] -i [inFolder] -o [outFolder] -w [windowSize] -l [minLen] -c [clipping] -g [fragments] -m [mode] -q [Qcutoff] -d [maxDataMB] -r [outMode]","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4ekee","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f1gjl","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9ngos","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Prowler command line options","description":"","guid":"1AA2D07280FE11EF8BB00A58A9FEAC02","name":"-f, 	--file,	               filename:  The name of the file you want to trim, 
-i, 	--infolder, 	inFolder:The folderpath where your file to be trimmed is located (default = cwd)
-o, 	--outfolder,	outFolder: The folderpath where your want to save the trimmed file (default = cwd)
-w, 	--windowsize,	windowSize:  Change the size of the trimming window (default= 100bp)
-l, 	--minlen,	                 minLen:  Change the minimum acceptable numer of bases in a read (default=100)
-m, 	--trimmode,	mode:		Select trimming algorithm: S for static  or D for dynamic (default=S)
-q, 	--qscore,	Qcutoff:	Select the phred quality score trimming threshold (default=7)
-d, 	--datamax,	maxDataMB:	Select a maximum data subsample in MB (default=0, entire file)
-r, 	--outformat,	outMode:	Select output format of trimmed file (fastq or fasta) (default=.fastq)
-c, 	--clip,		clipping:	Select L to clip leading Ns, T to trim trialing Ns and LT to trim both (default=LT)
-g, 	--fragments,	fragments:	Select fragmentation mode (default=U0)


[filename] = filename, including file extention (string)
[inFolder] = source folder (string)
[outFolder] = output folder (string)
[windowSize] = number of bases in trimmer window (integer)
[minLen] = minimum number of bases in read. reads with fewer bases will be rejected
[trimSpecs] = trim specs: [X1]-[X2]-[X3] (string)	
   X1: "L", "T", "LT", or "". L clips leading Ns, T clips trailing Ns, LT clips both, "" clips neither. recommended mode is LT	
   X2: U0, F0, F1, F2... U0=unfragmented output, F0=fragmented output with all fragments, F[n]= fragmented output with n largest fragments	
   X3: S, D. S=static mode. D=dynamic mode
	
   example: "X1-X2-X3" -> "LT-U0-S"

[Qcutoff] = phred quality score threshold. (integer)
[seqsToAnalyze] = megabytes of data to trim. trimmer will read files in 1 MB chunks and stop when number of MB exceeds this number.
[outMode]: output file extension. saves trimmed data as either ".fasta" or ".fastq"
","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"a52f5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4888r","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"apnup","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bc8lr","text":"Minimap2 is an alignment software developed to align short reads produced by ONT flow cells to a reference genome. Minimap2 has been proven to be faster and more accurate than other short read alignment softwares on the market currently. As the following quantification step via Salmon requires an input of SAM files, be sure to tell the program to output SAM files. Your input files should be gzipped .fasta, .fa, or .fq files obtained from the Prowler output. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"esjri","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"stcm","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2hqrf","text":"Creating reference index","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3gncf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"es4u0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"29af4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"48pim","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"epkpm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"atbtr","text":"In order to align the reads to a reference genome, you must create an index containing the reference genome of interest. Adjust demo script as needed to include/exclude options. Download the reference FASTA file for your organism of interest from the appropriate repository (eg. Flybase, Mouse Genome Informatics)","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"12ofd","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cggcr","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Reference index script ","description":"","guid":"444317CB80FF11EF84F70A58A9FEAC02","name":"minimap2 [-x preset] -d target.mmi target.fa\n","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4j621","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ahor","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7thav","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Minimap2 indexing options ","description":"","guid":"64ADE4C380FF11EF84F70A58A9FEAC02","name":"Indexing options
-k INT Minimizer k-mer length [15]

-w INT Minimizer window size [2/3 of k-mer length]. A minimizer is the smallest k-mer in a window of w consecutive k-mers.

-H Use homopolymer-compressed (HPC) minimizers. An HPC sequence is constructed by contracting homopolymer runs to a single base. An HPC minimizer is a minimizer on the HPC sequence.

-I NUM Load at most NUM target bases into RAM for indexing [4G]. If there are more than NUMbases in target.fa, minimap2 needs to read query.fa multiple times to map it against each batch of target sequences. NUM may be ending with k/K/m/M/g/G. NB: mapping quality is incorrect given a multi-part index.

--idx-no-seq Don’t store target sequences in the index. It saves disk space and memory but the index generated with this option will not work with -a or -c. When base-level alignment is not requested, this option is automatically applied.

-d FILE Save the minimizer index of target.fa to FILE [no dump]. Minimap2 indexing is fast. It can index the human genome in a couple of minutes. If even shorter startup time is desired, use this option to save the index. Indexing options are fixed in the index file. When an index file is provided as the target sequences, options -H, -k, -w, -I will be effectively overridden by the options stored in the index file.

--alt FILE List of ALT contigs [null]

--alt-drop FLOAT Drop ALT hits by FLOAT fraction when ranking and computing mapping quality [0.15]
","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b8jlm","text":"Aligning to reference index ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9hmag","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"35c0u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"138re","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8hiqu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9qgbk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Aligning to reference index","description":"","guid":"DE6090A580FF11EF84F70A58A9FEAC02","name":"minimap2 -a -x map-ont target.mmi your_sequences.fasta \u003e alignment.sam\n","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6qcb2","text":"For alignment and mapping options go to ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":46,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":46,"offset":0,"style":"UNDERLINE"}],"key":"q9pn","text":"https://lh3.github.io/minimap2/minimap2.html#5","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"ECA956E080FF11EFAC910A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://lh3.github.io/minimap2/minimap2.html#5"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c8c5p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b82gl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ed72a","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"82jf0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c7fui","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cnm8r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Convert SAM output to BAM using Samtools","description":"","guid":"FC1FA20680FF11EFAC910A58A9FEAC02","name":"samtools view -S -b alignment.sam \u003e alignment.bam\n","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5651c","text":"The accepted file format for quantification in alignment based format for Salmon is a .BAM file. Therefore, the output from the previous step will need to be converted to a BAM in Samtools.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"915ah","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ajpdu","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"43uv7","text":"Quantification using Salmon alignment based mapping ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"131dq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9h8ll","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c2bs8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d7gqc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Sample salmon script ","description":"","guid":"DE0FA7B3810011EF84F70A58A9FEAC02","name":"salmon quant --ont --noLengthCorrection -p 8 -t {input.transcriptome} -l U -a {input.bam} -o {output","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"27aad","text":"Salmon options can be found here ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":64,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":64,"offset":0,"style":"UNDERLINE"}],"key":"6sdpk","text":"https://salmon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/salmon.html#using-salmon","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1oe3t","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e2ptj","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"6609149A810111EF84F70A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://salmon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/salmon.html#using-salmon"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8a8bb","text":"Quantification prior to summarization to the counts level can be done via Salmon using the alignment-based method. For ONT reads, the option –noLengthCorrection MUST be used. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a6g0g","text":"Download the transcriptome file for your reference organism","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"di80l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"207ha","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3ejj1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7d4ps","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6jee5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2ojki","text":" In order to run EdgeR or DEseq2 you must have biological replicates for your results to be statistically significant. Without replicates, it is not possible to differentiate between random noise and differential expression. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
